Bruce,

Thank you for the information. it helped cue something
in my memory for further study.

I had two discussions on Tochibata tsuba while at the
Tampa show. 2 very different opinions. Interesting
topic. I think they are more remarkable for their iron
than their design.
   I have yet to find any papered to Tochibata in the
past 20 years. The advocates of it as a seperate
school seem to have died out.

Curran



--- bbmich3003 <brucemichener@...> wrote:

> Hi Curran et al:
> I have a Tochibata tsuba that I bought from a
> well-known Japanese 
> dealer. It is not papered, but, he wrote this info
> on the bill of 
> sale: " The old village of Tochihata eventually
> became Izumo in 
> Shimane Prefecture;  during early Edo, the tsubako
> of this village 
> specialized in making tsuba with the ji as carved
> rope, hence the 
> name Tochihata for this type of tsuba" [mine is a
> roped mimi].
> From this statement from him, I conjecture that a
> 'roped' mimi tsuba 
> called 'Tochibata' does't refer to a mei of
> "Tochibata", but to 
> having been made on the island of Tochibata. It is
> possible that 
> there are no tsuba with a mei "Tochibata".  I
> welcome all corrections 
> to the above. 
> 
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell
> 
> <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
> >
> > List,
> > 
> > I am hoping a lurker out there might be able to
> > comment on Tochibata tsuba. I am familiar with
> them as
> > written up on page 58-59 of Harry Watson's Nihonto
> > Koza translation of Kodogu Part 1.
> > 
> > I've seen a limited number of these over the
> years,
> > and they are distinct enough to me that I feel
> they
> > constitute a distinct _if minor_ school.
> > 
> > Q1:  Has anyone ever seen a tsuba NBTHK / NTHK
> papered
> > to Tochibata?
> > 
> > Q2:  Can anyone point me to further writing on
> this
> > school?
> > 
> > They tend to be strong solid open tsuba that
> remind of
> > Owari, are thick, yet very clean. The last I saw
> was
> > identical to the one on the bottom of NihontoKoza
> pg.
> > 59 and sold as "Owari".  I suspect the papering
> > authorities just designate them "Owari", but hope
> to
> > find an either one papered Tochibata or hope to
> find
> > another source beyond the Nihonto Koza.
> > 
> > Thanks in advance,
> > 
> > Curran
> > 
> > 
> >  
> > 
>
